content.text:
How do I Install an MC VA build version?

 

Refer to latest Release Notes for most accurate information.

 

Prereq: Your MC instance can access drp-sde.bluecoat.com

 

  • Identify the .bcsi image of the build you want
    • Log into cachezilla
      • Go to cachezilla.bluecoat.com
      • Click on the Login Icon
      • Username is: <first name>.<last name>
      • Password is your general Symantec password.
    • Navigate to Builds (Click on “Builds” in the menu bar at the top of the page).
    • Choose BCCM and the branch desired (ex. bccm_main)
    • Choose the build desired (should have green check in status column AND “Virtual Appliance Build PASSED” in comments column). Click on the "Build #" you desire.
    • Click on “Build Images” link
    • Click on “iso/”
    • Copy the URL of the .bcsi (either release or debug versions. Do not use AWS version)
  • Connect to ESX lab via vSphere client or web GUI
    • Draper Lab: https://10.131.38.100
    • User: root
    • Pass: lint1234
    • Our IP range: 10.131.38.0 thru 10.131.38.255. Reserve an IP at http://10.131.16.5/racktables/index.php?page=ipv4net&id=68(admin/lint1234)
    • SDE Lab: https://10.129.12.201
    • User/Pass: Your BCSECURE creds
    • Our IP range: 10.129.12.11 thru 10.129.12.50. Reserve an IP at https://symantec.jiveon.com/docs/DOC-63290
    • File > Deploy OVF template (use OVF from extracted .zip)
    • Name: (Should include IP, your name, and device type. For example “10.131.38.44 – David – MC Tester”)
    • Location: Make sure on an MC cluster. If in the SDE, pick .89 as the host
    • Thick provision lazy zeroed is fine
    • Open console on new thing to do initial boot. Start. Let it boot.
    • (ctrl+alt unlocks mouse from terminal)
    • Enter a valid serial number: Reserve a serial number at https://symantec.jiveon.com/docs/DOC-55796
  • MC Initial Config Setup - FOR SDE
    • IP addresses: (same as above)
    • Subnet mask: 255.255.252.0
    • Gateway: 10.129.12.1
    • DNS: 10.129.12.200
    • - FOR Draper lab -
    • IP address: (same as above)
    • Subnet mask: 255.255.255.0
    • Gateway: 10.131.38.1
    • DNS: 155.64.72.12
    • Password: lint1234 (or whatever you'd like)
  •  Now you should be able to access it via terminal on SDE
    • ssh admin@<ip> 
    • or via browser https://<ip>:8082https://%3cip%3e:8082

How do I Upgrade an MC VA to a particular build version?

 

Refer to latest Release Notes for most accurate information.

 

Prereq: Your MC instance can access drp-sde.bluecoat.com

 

  • Identify the .bcsi image of the build you want
    • Log into cachezilla
    • Navigate to Builds
    • Choose BCCM and the branch desired (ex. bccm_main)
    • Choose the build desired (should have green check in status column AND “Virtual Appliance Build PASSED” in comments column)
    • Click on “Build Images”
    • Click on “iso/”
    • Copy the URL of the .bcsi (either release or debug versions. Do not use AWS version)
  • Log into MC instance CLI
    • This will show the currently loaded images, their version, and the image selected for boot
    • Paste the URL of the desired .bcsi instance
    • After verification completes, restart instance
    • Either ssh admin@<ip>, open up console in vSphere, or open up CLI via UI (available in MC 2.2 and later)
    • #> enable
    • #> installed-systems view
    • #> installed-systems load <url>
    • #> restart
  • Wait for instance to restart

How do I Patch an MC VA with a partial build?

 

Making a patch moves any of your local changes to the VA. It does this by packaging your jars into a zip file.

 

There is a file that talks about how to do this. It is located at:

/Workspaces/bccm/dev_environment/tools and is called bccm_fns.sh.README.

 

  1. make a patch to use your changes with command "makepatch [MODULES]" eg "makepatch dev cm sg".
    1. The available modules can be found here: /Workspaces/bccm/dev_environment/tools/bccm_fns.sh
    2. If you want all of the jars you can use the alias "all" in place of  [MODULES].
    3. This transfers a zip of your jars to the sftp server.
  2. You must then retrieve it onto your va:

         ssh clpdebug@[your va] -p 2024
         password: 12345678
         $ sudo -s
         $ mount -o remount, rw /
         # sftp “BCSECURE\[your-login]“@[sftp server ip]:/[your-login]/bccm_patch.tgz /home/clpdebug
         # exit
         $ sudo tar --no-overwrite-dir -C / -xvf bccm patch.tgz && sudo restart bccm

 

 

Before run $ makepatch dev cm sg check the tar version as follows: tar --version

If tar version is 1.23, then create a Linux user bccm.

content.text:
To configure and deploy MC in AWS:

 

1. Install Amazon Command Line Interface (AWS CLI): 

pip install awscli

 

2. Configure the AWS CLI:

aws configure

Enter your:

         AWS Access Key ID:

         AWS Secret Key ID:

         Default region name: us-east-1

         Default output format: None

     

 

3. Save the attached AWSAMICreation.sh script file 

    Example: C:\AWS\AWSAMICreation.sh

 

4. Download bccm_main-232834-aws.debug.vhd.gz file from https://drp-sde.bluecoat.com/buildarchive/bccm_main.232834/iso  and unzip it.

    Example: C:\AWS\bccm_main-232834-aws.debug.vhd

 

5. Run the following command: 

./AWSAMICreation.sh bccm_main-232834-aws.debug.vhd BCCM_MAIN_232834

output of the above command:

 

6.Go to https://symc.sam.symantec.com and choose "Skyline AWS Access"

 

7. Choose MC-DEV Role from AWS Console Access. 

 

8. Choose existing EC2 instances and choose AMIs from images from Resources page.

 

9. Choose Amazon Machine Image. (AMI)

    Choose BCCM_Main_232834 Private image, and click Launch button.

 

10. Choose Instance Type.

    Minimum requirements  for MC:

      vCPUs: 2

      Memory(GiB): 4

      Type: t2 medium

 

11.  Configure Instance.

   Network: Select us-east-1-sysmc-dev01

   Subnet: MAKE SURE TO SELECT PRIVATE

Note: If we don't set the subnet to private and when we use debug version of MC images, that leads security vulnerabilities.

 

12. Advanced Details from Configure Instance page.

Select the User Data and chose the following URL to generate the JSON input user data https://support.symantec.com/content/unifiedweb/en_US/keygenerator.html

Make sure to select Management Center from the NPP AWS User Data Generator page.

Once you generated the user data you can paste it in the User data text box.

13. Add Storage.

By default 100 GiB is good enough 

 

14. Add Tags.

 

15. Configure Security Group

Choose the "Select existing security group" radio button and search “mcdev-production” from the list of existing group and select it.

 

 

16. Before Launching the instance, make sure everything looks correct from the Review page. After review click on the Launch button.

 

17. After launching the instance, all the running instances should be visible on the next page. The newly created MC instance should be running. Make sure the new MC instance's IP address is Private. 

 

18. Access the AWS deployed MC via using its IP address:

      SSH on port 22

      https via port 8082

 

20. Based on the selected security feature, http access is not available.

 

Note: 

a. When MC is deployed in AWS for testing purpose, make sure to terminate the instance after the usage. 

b. Port 9010 is for PDM collector. Devices send statistics data directly to MC.

content.text:
JIRA Terminology

  • Project. An individual product (such as MC, ProxySG, CAs, SSLV, etc)
  • Iteration. For our purposes, we will be treating each release as an iteration.
  • Feature. A chunk of functionality that delivers business value. Should be able to fit within one iteration, have a story points estimate, and be testable.
  • Preliminary Estimate. An estimate of the size/complexity of a Feature. Tracked by shirt-sizes (S, M, L, XL)
  • Story Points. An estimate of the effort (complexity, amount of work, risk, uncertainty) of work required to accomplish a story/task/bug. Story Points should be put on any individual element of work not already estimated somewhere else.
  • Story. Used to break down a Feature into smaller components, define Acceptance Criteria, and provide a Story Point estimate.
  • Task. Used to track elements that do not have direct business value (ex. branch merges, UX or Docs tasks, technical debt, etc)
  • Sub-Task. Not required. For developer’s convenience only. Generally used to break down a Story into smaller components.
  • Bug. A flaw or failure found in testing or production environments.
  • Merge Task. Used to track the need to merge code from one branch to another. Replaces Cachezilla's branch replicants

JIRA Methodology

Our usage of JIRA is broken down into four main phases: Planning, Development, Q/A, and Bug Tracking

Planning

In this phase feature requests are evaluated, prioritized, and organized into future releases.

Functionality: Features/bugs are inputted into MC backlog. PM, Architect, Dev Manager to sort out priority, plan into releases, flesh out details/descriptions, and assign Preliminary Estimates

Development

In this phase, development work is done on the features assigned to the current release.

Functionality: There are 5 stages in this phase: New, Ready, In Progress, QA Review, and Done.

  • Features from the Planning phase are initially put into a release in the New stage.
  • Architect or Dev Manager will move items into the Ready stage once they have enough detail.
  • Developers can pick up any unassigned items from the Ready stage.
  • To begin work on an item, Developers should:
    • Assign to self.
    • Move to In Progress by setting the Workflow Status to Develop.
    • Break into Stories with Acceptance Criteria and Story Point estimates.
      • Make sure to assign to self and set Fix Version to the correct release (these do not autopopulate)
      • Get approval from Architect, Dev Manager, or QA Manager on above.
      • Begin development work.
  • As Stories are completed, the developer should move them to the QA Review stage, by setting the Workflow Status to Resolved
  • Once all the Stories for a given Feature have been finished, remember to move the Feature to the QA Review stage as well (JIRA does not do this automatically)
  • If the Stories/Features fail to pass the Acceptance Criteria, the QA team will move the item(s) back into the Develop stage.

Q/A Review

In this phase individual features, stories, and bugs are tested for defects.

Functionality: QA team will periodically sweep items in the QA Review stage and test for defects. If the items pass, QA team will move them to Done. Otherwise, QA team will move them back to the Develop stage with notes/details on why it failed.

Bug Tracking

Issues identified outside of acceptance testing will be inputted and tracked here. This will be ongoing and run in parallel to the Planning-Development-QA cycle described above. It will be similar to the previous CZ process.

  • Once you start working on a bug, move it to the Develop workflow state.
  • If a bug fix will affect documentation, please add the "documentation impact" keyword
  • Please work on bugs in order of Priority not Severity. For example we will not ship with an S4 P1 since there is a typo in the UI
  • If you are going to take a bug from someone else, please consult with them before reassigning to yourself
  • If you have wrapped up your bugs, please help your teammates with their bugs
  • Please ensure that you have no more than 3 P1/P2 bugs at any time. Should those go beyond 3, please take a break from feature work and work on bugs
  • If you are working on a bug tagged for a released branch, create a merge task to fix the bug on main. For example, we have no intention to do a 1.10 patch so if there is a bug on 1.10, create a merge task to put the fix on the bccm_main branch.

 

 

Additional Details

 

Merge Tasks

If working on a bug that needs to be replicated to other branches, create a Merge Task (More > Create Sub-Task > Issue Type: Merge) and set the Fix Branch to the corresponding branch. Copy the summary from the original bug (do not just use a summary of "merge to main" or similar). Create additional merge tasks for each branch affected. This process will allow us to centralize tracking of a single bug across branches.

 

Check In Approval

If working on a bug/story/task for any branch other than bccm_main (ex. merging a bug from main to a patch release), you will need to obtain check in approval before being able to commit code against that item. Send a request to anyone with the "Approvers" role (ex. Dev Manager, Architect, QA Manager)

 

UX Integration

The UX team will be working directly in our JIRA project with us. They will mainly be using the "UX Tasks" kanban board. If you have an item that requires UX, create an issue of type "Task" (note: do not use "Sub-Task"), set it as "relates to" or "blocks" the dev item you're working on, and insert the tag "UX" in the labels field. Include a meaningful description of the UX work that is needed. Then alert the Dev Manager for prioritization on the UX board. The UX team will reach out to you directly if they have questions. You will be able to quickly view the status of the UX task from your own dev item by looking at the relates to section. Once UX has finished their task, they will upload a PDF copy onto their task and/or add notes/comments as appropriate and set their task as Done.

 

Docs Integration

The Docs team will be working directly in our JIRA project with us. They will mainly be using the "Docs Board" kanban board. If you have an item that will require documentation, set the "Docs Impacted" field to "Yes". It will show up on their board under the "Doc Impacts" swimlane and they will review and reach out with questions as needed.

content.text:
This document provides tips if you need to check LDAP connectivity from a machine on a given network to LDAP servers located outside that network.  Note that you may be able to successfully ping the LDAP servers you want to talk to, but that doesn't mean you can hit them over the LDAP port(s).  Also, you should really only ever use LDAP over SSL.  Using unencrypted LDAP over port 389 is *highly* discouraged.

 

 

Using telnet

You can use telnet as a crude tool to check if something is listening on the given port of a server.  In this way you can probe to see if the LDAP server you want is accessible over the network and can help you weed out firewall issues:

 

Failure due to firewall restrictions usually looks like this:

“

bash-4.1# telnet ldaps.symc.symantec.com 636

Trying 155.64.220.238...

telnet: connect to address 155.64.220.238: Connection refused

bash-4.1#

“

Success looks like this:

"

bash-4.1# telnet ldaps.symc.symantec.com 636

Trying 155.64.220.238...

Connected to ldaps.symc.symantec.com.

Escape character is '^]'.

^]

 

telnet> quit

Connection closed.

bash-4.1#

"

 

Now that is really all you need to verify connectivity from a network perspective.  If you want to make sure everything else is working on top of that (i.e. you have the right account/password, you can verify the server cert, you can make queries, etc.), there are methods below that accomplish this.

 

 

Using LDAP Admin

There is free, open-source tool that can be used to check connectivity to LDAP servers:

LDAP Admin - Wikipedia

LDAP Admin - a free LDAP directory browser and editor

This program lets you explore the structure of a directory on an LDAP server with a GUI which it is extremely helpful.

 

 

Using ldapsearch and/or ldapwhoami

For the examples we will use the following values when applicable:

Target AD LDAPS server:  ldaps.symantec.com

Target AD LDAP server:  ldap.symantec.com

Service Account (authorized to bind/query target LDAP server): CN=DPR.vCenter.auth,OU=Privileged_Non-Expiring,OU=Service Accounts,DC=SYMC,DC=SYMANTEC,DC=COM

CA Certificate: /tmp/verisign.cer

 

Use the following command for LDAPS:

env LDAPTLS_CACERT=/tmp/verisign.cer ldapsearch -H ldaps://ldaps.symc.symantec.com:636 -D 'CN=DPR.vCenter.auth,OU=Privileged_Non-Expiring,OU=Service Accounts,DC=SYMC,DC=SYMANTEC,DC=COM' -W -b '' -s base 'objectClass=*'

For regular LDAP use:

ldapsearch -H ldap://ldap.symc.symantec.com:389 -D 'CN=DPR.vCenter.auth,OU=Privileged_Non-Expiring,OU=Service Accounts,DC=SYMC,DC=SYMANTEC,DC=COM' -W -b '' -s base 'objectClass=*'

 

Success will output a bunch of attributes for the base object and output the following line near the end of the output:

"

result: 0 Success

"

Failure to contact the server (usually due to firewall or SSL issues) looks like:

“

ldap_sasl_bind(SIMPLE): Can't contact LDAP server (-1)

“

Wrong password looks like:

"

ldap_bind: Invalid credentials (49)

        additional info: 80090308: LdapErr: DSID-0C090400, comment: AcceptSecurityContext error, data 52e, v1db1

"

 

 

Use the following command for LDAPS:

env LDAPTLS_CACERT=/tmp/verisign.cer  ldapwhoami -H ldaps://ldaps.symc.symantec.com:636 -D 'CN=DPR.vCenter.auth,OU=Privileged_Non-Expiring,OU=Service Accounts,DC=SYMC,DC=SYMANTEC,DC=COM' -x -W

For regular LDAP use:

ldapwhoami -H ldap://ldap.symc.symantec.com:389 -D 'CN=DPR.vCenter.auth,OU=Privileged_Non-Expiring,OU=Service Accounts,DC=SYMC,DC=SYMANTEC,DC=COM' -x -W

 

Success will give you something like:

"

u:SYMC\DPR.vCenter.auth

Result: Success (0)

"

Failure to contact the server (usually due to firewall or SSL issues) looks like:

“

ldap_initialize( ldap://ldaps.symc.symantec.com:636 )

ldap_sasl_bind(SIMPLE): Can't contact LDAP server (-1)

“

Wrong password looks like:

"

ldap_bind: Invalid credentials (49)

        additional info: 80090308: LdapErr: DSID-0C090400, comment: AcceptSecurityContext error, data 52e, v1db1

"

 

"env" is just a command that runs a command in a modified environment.  In this case the command is ldapsearch or ldapwhoami, and we just want to have an environment variable set that will point to the CA certificate used to trust the cert sent to us by the AD LDAP server during the SSL handshake.

 

Note that running these commands will prompt for the password associated with the service account specified in the bind DN option (-D) of the commands.

There are also verbose (-v, -vv, -vvv) and debug level (-d [0-7]) options for these commands which are useful to determine why the connection failed (i.e. was failure in SSL handshake, was it a timeout, etc.)

 

 

Using Perl

If you feel like using Perl, you can use the 'ldap.pl' script in the 'ldap.zip' file attached to this document as a jumping off point.  Mainly it was based on a Perl snippet posted in a comment in Key Info to Migrate to GDS LDAP (which is for people trying to setup authentication to the Symantec GDS LDAP servers, in contrast to using Symantec AD LDAP servers which were used in this this document for examples)

list.subject: Checking for LDAP Connectivity

content.text:
The vCenter 10.131.38.100 is used primarily by the Management Center team under Puru Kamath.

 

Designated Administrators

Administrators of this vCenter are (as of the time of this writing):

Puru Kamath

Nathan Fife

 

How to Access

vSphere Web Client: https://10.131.38.100:9443

Desktop Client (a.k.a. thick client) download link: https://10.131.38.100/client/VMware-viclient.exe

 

Authentication Domains

vCenter is configured to search a list of domains when authenticating a user who is attempting to log in to the vSphere Web Client or the desktop client.  The following domains define collections of users that are allowed to log in to vCenter. :

  • SYMC
  • CF-CAL
  • VSPHERE.LOCAL

Note that there is an internal domain on the vCenter called "localos" that contains backend system users.  These shouldn't be used to log in to the vCenter via Web Client or vSphere desktop client.  This domain should be ignored.

 

To add authentication domains, see Adding an Authentication Domain to vCenter.

 

Domain Notes

SYMC

Users using SYMC domain logins must use the NetBIOS syntax (known in Active Directory as "NT Logon name") for now.  It has the format "SYMC\Firstname_Lastname".

 

Note that inability to use the "userPrincipalName" to log in (i.e. Firstname_Lastname@symantec.com; which is the same as one's email address) may be due to SYMC not being the default domain at the moment; once CF-CAL is removed from vCenter and SYMC is set to default we may be able to log in with "@symantec.com" email addresses.  If this isn't the cause, more investigation may need to be performed to enable logins with just the SYMC username or userPrincipalName.

 

SSO identity source setup for SYMC uses the following values:

Identity source type*Active Directory as a LDAP Server
NameSYMC-AD
Base DN for users**DC=SYMC,DC=SYMANTEC,DC=COM
Domain namesymc.symantec.com
Domain aliasSYMC
Base DN for groupsOU=Groups,DC=SYMC,DC=SYMANTEC,DC=COM
Primary server URLldaps://ldaps.symc.symantec.com:636
Secondary server URL<empty>
Certificate***<see notes below>
Username****CN=DPR.vCenter.auth,OU=Privileged_Non-Expiring,OU=Service Accounts,DC=SYMC,DC=SYMANTEC,DC=COM

 

*There is an alternative to using AD LDAP called GDS LDAP and is a completely different set of LDAP servers.  This method of authentication was not used because Justin Rohbock was under the impression that it would require querying special Symantec-defined attributes for the username, and there was no way to specify this in vCenter's identity source setup.  See also: Key Info to Migrate to GDS LDAP

 

**The recommended base DN for users is actually "OU=People,DC=SYMC,DC=SYMANTEC,DC=COM".  The reason we had to widen the scope of the search is to accommodate the Project Lighthouse team’s service account ‘SYMC\SWI.Tools.2’.  It lives under "OU=Non-Personnel,OU=Special Use Accounts,DC=SYMC,DC=SYMANTEC,DC=COM", not "OU=People,DC=SYMC,DC=SYMANTEC,DC=COM".  Using a wider search for users like this seems to slow down logins.  If we want to change this in the future we could simply give the Project Lighthouse team a new user defined in VSPHERE.LOCAL to use and then change our base DN for SYMC users to be more narrow again. It's not possible to just split the SYMC-AD identity source into two separate identity sources both pointing to the same SYMC AD LDAP servers, but with different base DNs (i.e. one for users and one for non-personnel special use accounts).  See here and here for confirmation that doesn't work.  Although we may be able to speed things up if we open up the "Global Catalog" ports Microsoft Active Directory and use those instead.  This assumes that the Symantec AD LDAP servers expose that port at all.

 

***The certificate used for the SYMC-AD identity source is in "Administration" --> "Single Sign-On" --> "Configuration" under the "Certificates" tab in the "Identity Sources TrustStore".   The "Subject" of the cert has a CN of "CN=VeriSign Class 3 Public Primary Certification Authority -G5".  The cert was provided by  Irwin Naumann and installed by Justin Rohbock.  The cert is attached to this document as a zip file 'verisign.zip'

 

****Note that "DPR.vCenter.auth" is a "Privileged" "Non-expiring" service account in the SYMC AD LDAP domain that was created by way of Service Exchange request ticket.  Responsibility for this particular service account is currently assigned to Puru Kamath and Justin Rohbock. If you need to create a new service account, see related instructions in Adding an Authentication Domain to vCenter.

 

 

CF-CAL

Use of the CF-CAL domain is deprecated, and the domain will be retired soon.

CF-CAL domain logins can use NetBIOS syntax (CF-CAL\Firstname.Lastname) or you can use your old Blue Coat email address.

 

For reference, SSO Identity source setup for CF-CAL used the following values:

Identity source typeActive Directory as a LDAP Server
NameBlueCoat (CF-CAL)
Base DN for usersDC=internal,DC=cacheflow,DC=com
Domain nameinternal.cacheflow.com
Domain aliasCF-CAL
Base DN for groupsDC=internal,DC=cacheflow,DC=com
Primary server URLldap://pwdrp-adrwdc-01.internal.cacheflow.com:3268
Secondary server URLldap://pwdrp-adrwdc-02.internal.cacheflow.com:3268
UsernameCN=svcWebPulse,OU=Service Accounts,DC=internal,DC=cacheflow,DC=com

 

VSPHERE.LOCAL

This is a built-in domain where you can define local users.  VSPHERE.LOCAL domain logins should use NetBIOS syntax (i.e. VSPHERE.LOCAL\username).

There is a built-in user VSPHERE.LOCAL\Administrator that has Administrator privileges.

list.subject: vCenter 10.131.38.100 (Draper Lab)

content.text:
Note:  You must have Administrator permissions on the "vCenter Server" object in your vCenter to perform the configuration described in this document.  As far as I know at the time of this writing, users must have these permissions to even see the "Single Sign-On" part of the navigation tree. If you can't see "Single Sign-On" in the navigation tree or you already know you lack permissions, please see the individual designated as your administrator for your lab's vCenter instance for assistance.  At minimum, they should be able to access the default user 'VSPHERE.LOCAL\Administrator' that has these necessary permissions by default.

 

Different authentication domains can be added by logging in to the vSphere Web Client (e.g. https://10.131.38.100:9443) and navigating to "Administration" --> "Single Sign-On" --> "Configuration".  Here you can add a new domains as an "Identity Source" under the tab "Identity Sources".  In this document we'll only provide guidance on configuring an "Active Directory as a LDAP server" identity source type.

 

You'll want to make sure that you have a clear path through whatever network firewalls and filters may be in place between you and whatever LDAP servers you are trying to authenticate to.  If necessary, you may have to submit a Firewall Change Request (FCR).  You'll also want to make sure you have an account that vCenter can use to query the LDAP servers.  Generally these type of accounts are referred to as "service accounts".  You'll want a service account created in the same domain as you are trying to authenticate users against (i.e. to authenticate SYMC users, you'll want a SYMC service account).  After you've got that sorted out, it's a simple matter of filling in boxes in the "Edit identity source" dialog box (example SSO identity source setup values can be found in vCenter 10.131.38.100 (Draper Lab) under the section "Domain Notes").

 

You can log directly into the shell of the vCenter appliance via SSH using a 'localos' domain user (like 'root') and perform some of the tests in Checking for LDAP Connectivity to sanity check the LDAP connection.  (Note that vCenter doesn't have telnet installed, but you can pick a machine on the same subnet as the vCenter that does and try from there.)

 

 

Submitting a Firewall Change Request (FCR)

If you need to change firewall rules for LDAP access, go to Service Exchange  > Make a Request > Technology Services > Network Services > Request a Change to Firewall Rules.  Make sure you read the instructions at the top of the page, specifically the link to more detailed instructions at Submit a Firewall Change Request.  If you require more guidance on filling out the forms, you can contact Puru Kamath and/or Roger Harrison.

(For reference, the ticket#RITM0303904 was used to allow LDAP communication with Symantec AD LDAP servers over ports 389 and 636 from the MC subnets in the Draper lab)

 

Creating a Service Account

If you need to create a service account you can go to Service Exchange  > Make a Request > Technology Services > Hosting Services > Request Service Account for Application Elevated Access.  (On the form for the question "Will this account be used on a SOX or PCI compliant system?" I put "Yes" and then in the description wrote the following "I do not know what SOX or PCI means in this context and I do not know if the vCenter I will be using the account for is SOX or PCI compliant."  The IT folks seemed to be satisfied with that answer and the resulting service account did work for vCenter to query AD LDAP.)

(For reference, the ticket#RITM0298204 was used to create a service account "DPR.vCenter.auth")

content.text:
Feature Description

Rally story: US21284 - CLI: migrate "backup" command

 

 

RoleName
DeveloperAnton Andreev
Architect
QA

 

Feature Requirements

  • Continue to offer compatible backup functionality to MC 1.x
    • transferable between appliances
    • backup applicable to same appliance version only
    • includes all UI settings and bccm database
    • by default includes partial appstats db (no trend data due to its size)
      • historic trend data is to be exported separately from backup
    • includes partial system settings (user added certificates, NTP...)
    • backup does not include:
      • user password
      • license
      • server certificate
  • Disable customers editing backups off-box directly

 

 

High Level Design


MC originally was planning to use COE's F1627 [COE Configuration Management ], which would offer backup functionality for the device.  However, the feature is incomplete for COE 3.19 and does not offer a way to save ConfD configuration without using alliance's MEK (major impediment) and does not offer export/import functionality.  Given that configuration includes complete Confd database, IP and user passwords (encrypted with MEK), it is not usable on other appliances or appliances that were factory restored.

 

For the time being we are left with an option to implement our own Backup functionality.  MC would store parts of CDB to not loose functionality of 1.x, currently this includes /ssl, /ntp, /snmp, /event-log.  Configuration containing encrypted data using MEK would need to be decrypted before storing in the archive (any passwords).

 

Backup archives should be stored on encrypted partition since it contains sensitive information (COE is doing this with configuration management).  Given that MC 1.x allocations 5GB to this partition, backups will continue to be stored in the same location but will be encrypted with "per box" generated key.  Before exporting backup, as in MC 1.x, user must be prompted for passphrase.  This passphrase needs to be amended with hard-coded string to disallow customers editing backups off-box directly.

 

Previously in MC 1.x, customers had a choice to include/exclude trend data from backup via full/partial backup options.  With MC 2.x we have an option to keep similar feel or separate appstats database import/export under statistics monitoring CLI function.

 

 

Security Considerations

  • Backups stored on appliance will be encrypted with "per appliance" key
  • Exported backup will require a user passphrase that will be amended with hard-coded value to prevent customers changing backups offbox

 

Upgrade/Downgrade

Upgrade

  • Existing MC 1.x backup will be deleted on upgrade

list.subject: MC Backup Feature Design

content.text:
Overview

The Management Center build contains a custom plugin that will scan dependencies based on the Maven dependency tree for a project and verify that the license type for any included artifact conforms to the Symantec OSS standards.

 

Using the Plugin

There is a MVN profile in top level project that validates licensing on Central Management.  This profile is not enabled by default, but it is now enabled on the build server.  What that means for developers is that from now on whenever you add a new dependency in aproject - please do a top level build with ‘licenseAttribution’ profile enabled.

 

bccm> mvn clean install –Pdevelopment,licenseAttribution

 

The build may fail if the dependency does not have a supported license or does not have a license specified.

 

Handling Licensing Errors

There are 2 types of errors that might be reported by the plugin.  The first is that a license that is not in the approved list is found.  The other is when license information is not available for a module.

 

Unrecognized License

If the problem is that the license is already approved but has a different name or label in the package, you have to add it to the list of known license labels.

To do this, you checkout /mojo-parent/pom.xml and add the license to the existing license in the <licenseMerges> section.

You will then rebuild the plugin and test it.

bccm> mvn clean install –PbuildMojoParentArtifact

Once you are sure it works correctly, kick of the mojo-parent build on the Jenkins server in order to update the build server.

 

Missing License

If you use a package that does not have license information in it, you need to research the package to confirm the license type.   If it conforms to one of the valid license types you will then add it to the THIRD-PARTY.properties file.  To specify a missing license for a  dependency please add a dependency with a license to <maven module>/src/license/THIRD-PARTY.properties.  Format for doing so is as follows:

<groupId>--<artifactId>--<version>=License Name goes here

Please look at one of the existing examples, such as bccm.client/src/license/THIRD-PARTY.properties.

 

Excluding components from License Attributions

You may choose to exclude components from attributions in such cases as components has commercial license or component is only used for build/test (ie not shipped with the product).  To do so edit top level file thirdparty-attribution-exclusions.txt located along side top-level-pom of bccm project.  If a process encounters a component name that starts with a string listed in above mentioned file, it will be omitted from the attributions.

 

Including non-java components in License Attributions

There are cases when we want to include open source non-java licenses of components used by bccm, such as javascript or hardware diagnostics attributions.  For those cases please add license files to the following locations: <top-level-bccm>/bccm.attributions/doc/thirdparty-attributions and hardware-diagnostic-attributions.  Please take a look at existing structure for examples.

 

 

Reference material

Open Source Approvals and Tracking in COE

content.text:
• Rally
    • The user story you are working on should be associated with a feature. If not, please let Puru or Brian know before starting work.
    • The story should be in a defined state before you start working on it unless you created the user story.
    • Add an initial estimate for the user story (usually done during sprint planning unless you wrote the story afterwards)
    • If the "FS Required" field is set to yes, please write a design document in the user story and get it approved by Brian before proceeding with implementation
      • Please use the attached Functional Specification Template.docx and post it to Functional Specs sub-space under the Management Center space on share. Submit to Brian and me for review and approval. We'll then include the team we are integrating with and have them review and approve.
    • Add at least 1 tasks with hour estimates
    • Update Rally task(s) at least once a day
    • The user story or feature should have an associated bug in CZ so you can commit code changes. Create a bug of the format "F2425-Collect sysinfo for SWG-VR" or with the user story number and name so there is better trace-ability.
  • CZ
    • Once you start working on a bug assigned to you, move it to the "ASSIGNED" state from the "NEW" state. For bugs logged by QA, please work with QA if you are unable to reproduce the bug. Feel free to move the bug to BLOCKED state (Do not close the bug as WORKSFORME/INVALID without consulting with the QA engineer that wrote the bug)
    • If a bug fix will affect documentation, please add the "documentation impact" keyword
    • Please work on bugs in order of Priority not Severity. For example we will not ship with an S4 P1 since there is a typo in the UI
    • If you are going to take a bug from someone else, please consult with them before reassigning to yourself
    • If you have wrapped up your bugs, please help your teammates with their bugs during our Code Complete milestone phase
    • Please ensure that you have no more than 3 P1/P2 bugs at any time. Should those go beyond 3, please take a break from feature work and work on bugs
    • If you are working on a bug for a released branch, mark the bug on the branch as WONTFIX and fix the bug on main. For example, we have no intention to do a 1.10 patch so if there is a bug on 1.10, mark that as WONTFIX and put the fix on the bccm_main branch.
  • Dev Testing and Reviews
    • Unit tests are encouraged. We have a BU goal of increasing unit tests and code coverage for our products
    • Unit tests will be required for device plugins since this is where we've seen the most number of bugs off late
    • Test to ensure that a new feature or bug fix didn't break related features or change their behavior. An example would be to test that the CAS 2.x plugin continues to function with CAS 1.x assuming its the same plugin
    • Code reviews are encouraged and in some cases will be required (at Brian, Rick and Puru's discretion). If you believe you are working on a complicated piece of code and want to pair with someone, that is encouraged also
    • Everyone is encouraged to look at everyone else's code and provide feedback.
  • Code Check-ins
    • Check-in early and often during the feature development process so people can provide feedback sooner in the process to avoid rework.
    • Ensure that your build will pass locally before you check-in. If jshint wont pass locally, it will not pass on the build server.
    • Shelve your changes so if your SDE machine is corrupted, your changes aren't lost. Perforce makes this easy and if you don't know how to do this, ask.
    • Include the bug number, bug description and a description of the change with every check in. If you got it code reviewed, feel free to include that info also
  • Documentation
    • Docs team will provide an initial draft a few days after the demo. Please take the time to review and provide feedback.
  • Skills Transfer
    • Skills transfer for a release happens soon after feature complete. The expectation is to have at least 1 slide per user story or feature

This document is a DRAFT and does not represent authoritative design guidelines at this point.  Comments are welcome.

This document comes to address the requirements from Rally feature request F1280 to provide CLI commands for applications services framework on COE via ConfD.

 

Component Name

TBD

 

RoleName
DeveloperJustin Rohbock
Code ReviewerTBD:

Use Cases (Optional)  Written from the viewpoint of the feature's audience (either developer or end-user)

//TODO

 

Feature Requirements

  • Register a service
  • Stop a service
  • Start a service
  • Display status of service
    • Name
    • Running/Stopped state
    • CPU usage [not in stage I of feature]
    • Memory usage [not in stage I of feature]
  • Expose list of services via ConfD
  • Expose service status via ConfD

 

Design Describe the feature design

A "service" in the context of this feature is an abstract piece of functionality that runs on the system as a daemon.  It is convenient for the purposes of this feature to think about the existing services that product teams have as black box processes.  For existing services created by product teams, this includes all of the configuration (values of settings, firewall rules for network access, etc.), logging, startup and shutdown behavior that the daemon needs to be useful on the system (and all of these details are already managed via other channels).  This feature will provide a user-facing interface for basic management of these services at runtime.  "Management" in this sense is very simplistic and will consist of being able to stop and start the services as well as viewing their current status.  In short, providing any standardized way to change the details of the services themselves is outside the scope of this feature.

 

Examples of existing services in the Management Center product:

  • "Management Center UI" - This is an Upstart service that's primary function is to run the Virgo Tomcat web server that serves the main Javascript web GUI to clients.  It reads configuration from miscellaneous properties files, firewall rules allow it to communicate over port 8080 and 8082, and it stores/reads data from a Postgres database.
  • "Report Generator" - This is an Upstart service that runs a Java-based daemon that services requests on the loopback interface to format data shown on the web GUI into downloadable HTML and PDF reports.
  • "Statistics Monitoring" - This is an Upstart service that runs a C/C++ daemon that serves as an upload point for PDM statistics data from other devices (ProxySG).  The service file (appstats.conf) is hard-coded to provide arguments to the daemon on start that point to log location and the config file(s) from which it reads/stores configuration values.

All of these services have their own logging, settings files, and other miscellaneous interactions with the system and these details will not be managed by this feature.

 

A static list of services will be kept in ConfD (specifically CDB in memory) that will be linked to data provider callbacks that will expose status when queried by ConfD.  Standard action callbacks will be used to start, stop, and restart a given service from the list of services.  Status of services can be queried from ConfD via a "status" command provided by action callback, the built-in show command on the CLI, and via REST API query.

 


APIs

Runtime API will be all northbound agents of ConfD.

From an application team perspective, the API to load/register a new service will be loading XML data into CDB via standard COE 3.x infrastructure to populate the services list. //TODO talk about operational data loading

To remove/un-register a service(s) the ConfD command "confd_cmd" can be invoked as "confd_cmd -o -c 'delete <conf path to services list>'" to delete the entire services list in ConfD and then the new services list can be loaded.

 

Product Team Data API

This will simply be an XML initialization file that is provided by the product team and placed in a pickup directory for COE ConfD framework to load:

"

<services xmlns="http://www.bluecoat.com/bluecoat-cm-main">

    <service>

        <name>Management Center UI</name>

        <internal-name>bccm</internal-name>

        <servicetype>UPSTART</servicetype>

        <autocomplete-desc>The web interface for Management Center</autocomplete-desc>

    </service>

    <service>

        <name>Some Job</name>

        <internal-name>somejob</internal-name>

        <servicetype>UPSTART</servicetype>

        <autocomplete-desc>Some test job I made sleeps for 120 seconds when started</autocomplete-desc>

    </service>

</services>

"

Note: If no services are defined, then the services list and all child nodes/actions in the data model should be hidden in the CLI and REST APIs.

 

 

REST API

//See REST API question on lingering questions

 

 

CLI Commands  List any new CLI commands (including syntax and all parameters) for this feature.


//Operational mode

# system-services ?

list restart start status stop

# system-services start ?

<name>

# system-services stop ?

<name>

# system-services restart ?

<name>

# system-services status ?

<name>

# system-services status <name>

name <name>

status <state>


# system-services list

NAME                  STATUS            

-------------------------------------------

Management Center UI  <state> 

Some Job              <state> 


# show system-services

NAME                  STATUS            

-------------------------------------------

Management Center UI  <state> 

Some Job              <state> 

 

 

 

<name> -- string; not mutable by end-user

<state> -- string; confined to values "running" or "stopped"

 

Supported Platforms

All versions of COE 3.x >= 3.19.

 

Dependencies

COE and ConfD Infrastructure

Upstart service support. (implied by COE)

System V service support. (implied by COE) //See Lingering Questions section for whether we need this


Assumptions

Dynamic registration/de-registration (i.e. add/remove) of services at runtime by the user is not required.

Instance jobs that are parameterized need not be supported since managing them will not be exposed to end users. (For example, Upstart job for MC "bccm-shell-tty" runs two instances that show like "bccm-shell-tty (/dev/tty1) start/running, process 4480" and "bccm-shell-tty (/dev/ttyS0) start/running, process 4486")

 

Performance Considerations  Will this feature impact performance in any way? Are there any mitigations?

A relatively speaking, scraping the data off the system for the CPU and memory usage [not part of stage I of feature] when populating those parts of the operational data model would be more expensive than providing just the status (started/stopped) for a given service.

 

Scaling Considerations  Does the feature scale with respect to higher link speeds, connection rates, processors, etc.?

Requests for service information will require the data-provider callbacks to populate the data model by scraping system data which may be relatively slow.  Many requests for service information in a short period of time from an automated usage of ConfD REST API could possibly bottleneck.  This could be mitigated with a caching scheme (as shown in ConfD example "/opt/tailf/confd/examples.confd/cli/show_rewrite/Demo.java), but we would need to decide on an acceptable cache window.  Too large and requests for service information will return outdated info, too short and you end up wasting processing refreshing data that hasn't changed.  Note that this may not even be a realistic concern depending on actual use cases, and for stage I of the feature we will just grab the status and return it directly on demand.

 

Security Considerations

End users (i.e. ConfD agents) will not be able to change the contents of the list of services and the operations that will be possible will be limited to start, stop, restart, status (any arguments will need to be validated; they will have to have an entry in the services list in ConfD).

Other considerations?

 

Feature Risks  What risks does this feature present?

User-defined services will be confined to Upstart and SystemV.

Exposing service management to end-users for services that have inter-dependencies may produce minor confusion, since the user would have no direct visibility into the dependencies.  (if user can manage two services and service A automatically starts/stops/restarts service B they may not be expecting that)

Other considerations?

 

Upgrade/Downgrade Considerations  Describe any issues or factors to consider related to this feature when upgrading or downgrading.

How do we add/update/remove a service?  The list of services will be effectively static for a running system image.  When upgrading/downgrading to a different system image the service list will be loaded from the XML when ConfD eventually starts up.  The service list will be able to differ between product versions by providing updated initialization XML with the different images.

Other considerations?


Test Plan  Guidelines written by developer initially and then details filled out by QA.

//TODO


Lingering Questions Ideally these will all be answered through the design phase and their answers will be incorporated into the rest of this document

What do we mean by "CPU usage" and "Memory usage" as far as requirements go?

  • Is the even computed the same way for different services' processes? 
  • Would we want to use a pluggable architecture (similar to Health Monitoring "metrics") to allow arbitrary statistics to be reported?
  • Do we want average CPU usage or more real-time?
  • Memory usage statistics can be private, shared, resident/physical, virtual, etc. so what we want to report would vary on the driving requirements.
  • Anything else that should be included as part of the status?


Exposure of hidden data during backup/restore of ConfD?  Logging of events exposing it?


Do we even care about different types of services? (i.e. Upstart vs SystemV vs SystemD)


We could easily make it so that the services themselves (i.e. the name and service type) are stored as config data so that services could be dynamically added/removed using Maapi and not having to resort to confd_load/confd_cmd.  (Essentially, we have the list be hidden config data exposed only to maapi and then have an operational service list mirror that config by using a DataProvider callback that reads the config list with Maapi)


Case-sensitivity of arguments and autocomplete?

list.subject: Application Services Design Doc

content.text:
For syntactical convenience, the hypothetical new branch will be referred to as "bccm_new".  (MC branch names for release branches follow a pattern where the numerals correspond to the version of MC that is being released from that branch:  1.9.x.y >>> bccm_1_9;  1.10.x.y >>> bccm_1_10;  1.11.x.y >>> bccm_1_11;  2.0.x.y >>> bccm_2_0; etc.)

 

The phrase "create a branch" means different things to different people in different contexts.  However, to create a fully formed branch suitable for spawning a release build, quite a few things that need to happen.  In this document we will try to be precise.  For instance, when we refer to the "P4 branch" or the "Cachezilla branch" those are two separate things, the first is creation of a new directory in our source tree for branch files and the other is configuration of Cachezilla to have a new selectable branch.

 

Throughout this document there will be references to examples of previous changelists and bug numbers that demonstrate where a certain action was done for a previous branch.  It is recommended to use the changelist descriptions of those examples as templates for your own changelists as they include useful information information (such as why the files are being modified in the ways they are, which helps when you or someone else have to branch again a few months down the road.  Another important thing is spelling out which changelists were included in a initial merge or mass-merge which is useful when trying to sum up the state of the branch for the rest of the team at the end of this whole process).

 

A recording/tutorial of the branching process for bccm_1_11 can be found Here

 

 

      • Order of operations when branching
      • Creating a branch directory in the source tree in Perforce.
      • Creating a branch in Cachezilla.
        • Restricting check-ins to require Cachezilla bugs
        • Restricting check-ins to require approval.  (i.e. "freezing" a CZ branch)
      • Creating build jobs on Jenkins.
      • Initial merge/population of the source tree bccm_main --> bccm_new
        • Create a bug on the new bccm_new CZ branch to track branching work
        • Create applicable branch mappings in P4
      • Configuration of build files and assigning initial COE lock:
      • Remove any vestigial code that isn't actually part of the build.
      • Change internal components version (i.e. bundles, RPMs, other assorted files)
      • Update development shell scripts (to use proper Java and JS compiler versions)
      • Mass-merge syncing new changelists from bccm_main to bccm_new (optional)
      • Creating Koji tags.
      • Checking build and dev environment locally for bccm_new
      • Enable build jobs.
      • Notification of dev team and QA that branch has been created.

 

 

Order of operations when branching

Generally the most straightforward way to do branching is shown in the following image:

Note:  This isn't necessarily 100% set in stone, and you will undoubtedly have to be flexible and update this as time progresses and our dev process changes.  For sure the stuff in the green-outlined box in the image can be done in any order.

 

 

Creating a branch directory in the source tree in Perforce.

ES will need to have a directory for the new branch visible in Perforce in order to create the Cachezilla branch (because they need a directory to exist in order to properly test their stuff when creating a new CZ branch).  Merely committing a single a single file anywhere under //bccm/bccm_new/ qualifies.  It's convenient to choose something that hasn't/won't change from bccm_main to bccm_new.  A good choice is //bccm/bccm_main/Makefile >>> //bccm/bccm_new/Makefile

 

Why not just create the branch directory fully populated with contents from bccm_main?  Because we can't create a bug to track branch creation until we have a branch in CZ, and we want to track as much as possible against actual bugs in CZ.  So we populate only a single dummy file to get a branch directory in P4 to show up, which allows ES to create a branch in CZ.  Once we've got a CZ branch we can log a "branch creation" bug on that branch of MC that will track the P4 commits under one roof (including the initial population of bccm_new from bccm_main).

 

Example changelist for this is CL#825646 for bccm_1_11

 

 

Creating a branch in Cachezilla.

Restricting check-ins to require Cachezilla bugs

ES requires you to explicitly request Cachezilla/Perforce integration behaviors be enabled (a.k.a. "Perforce triggers"); they do not enable them by default.  So if you want to have check-ins under bccm_new require a bug, add a provision such as "Enable Perforce integration trigger requiring every check-in to this branch to be associated with a Cachezilla bug on this branch (czBugSubmit.pl)" to the ticket you file for ES branching tasks.

The only reference I ever found for Perforce triggers on share is in New Branch and Build Setup for ProxyAV.  According to email from Rajeev "the bug-required-for-every-check-in trigger name is czBugSubmit.pl", so we can explicitly reference that file by name in our request or use refer to the behavior with vague verbage like "trigger requiring every check-in to this branch to be associated with a Cachezilla bug on this branch".

 

Restricting check-ins to require approval.  (i.e. "freezing" a CZ branch)

Similarly, to require check-in approval for a bug you must ask for it to be enabled for your branch when you file a ticket for ES branching tasks.  A provision such as "Freeze the "bccm_new" branch.  (i.e. enable Perforce trigger requiring check-in approval)" should be sufficient

 

The actual creation of the branch in CZ is done by ES, please see Creating build jobs on Jenkins for details.

 

 

Creating build jobs on Jenkins.

Creating a branch in CZ and build jobs on the Jenkins production servers is controlled by Engineering Services.  You will have to file an ES ticket to DL-ENG-ES@symantec.com (optionally cc'ing Rajeev) asking for bccm_new branching tasks to be completed.  It's important to be very explicit with ES; they will only do what you ask, exactly what you ask, and absolutely nothing more.  After they have completed this work there will be a new branch in the menus when searching/filing bugs on Cachezilla which we can then use to create a bug to track the rest of our branching work on our end.  The build jobs will also be created, but disabled.  We will have to enable them later (if we enabled them now we'd just be bombarded with failed build notifications and no-one wants that).

 

Full text example template for ES request for a new release branch with typical parameters:

To: DL-ENG-ES@symantec.com

Subject: bccm_new branching tasks

Body:

"

+Please create a "bccm_new" branch in Cachezilla.

+Enable Perforce integration trigger requiring every check-in to this branch to be associated with a Cachezilla bug on this branch (czBugSubmit.pl)

+Freeze the "bccm_new" branch after creation.  (i.e. enable Perforce trigger requiring check-in approval)

+Please create Jenkins build jobs for a "bccm_new" branch using "bccm_main" build jobs as a template and ensure these new build jobs are initially DISABLED.   Product team will then branch source code and specify configuration in files and THEN notify ES via this ticket when we want to enable jobs and try a build.

+Please enable auto-replication of new bccm_new bugs in Cachezilla to bccm_main.  Auto-replication between bccm_new and bccm_main should be unidirectional.  (i.e. we want bccm_new --> bccm_main auto-replication, but not bccm_main --> bccm_new).

+Koji tags have been/will be created by MC team using "Create-Koji-Tag-Hierarchy" Jenkins Dev Utils job.

 

NOTE: The Reactor build step for the new bccm_new jobs has a Maven/pom filename parameter.  Currently it's set to "bccm_main" and it should be changed to "bccm_new" to match the branch.  This is necessary for Reactor build to succeed.

NOTE: The P4 client spec for the new build jobs should be set up to be defined by the checked in file //bccm/bccm_new/p4.cs

"

 

 

Initial merge/population of the source tree bccm_main --> bccm_new

 

Create a bug on the new bccm_new CZ branch to track branching work

You'll want to create a "branch creation" bug in CZ to track of all of the changes you make when configuring a new branch.  This is for book-keeping and your own sanity.  There's a lot of stuff going on and having it in one place is helpful (especially when you're branching again in three months and want a reliable reference).

 

Create applicable branch mappings in P4

You'll want a branch mappings in Perforce to simplify merges between bccm_new and existing branches (primarily bccm_main).  The standard branch mapping naming pattern is "BCCM-<branch#1>-to-<branch#2>".  These mappings can be used bidirectionally, so you'll only need one for each pair of branches you want to do merges between.  We can always create new branch mappings later if we need them, but we will at least need one mapping between bccm_new and the branch we are using to initialize it (i.e. bccm_main).

 

When you right click a branch (doesn't matter which one) and click "Merge/Integrate" you'll get a dialog box.  If you select "Use branch mapping" for the "Merge method:" you can create a "New" branch mapping. Create a new branch mapping "BCCM-bccm_main-to-bccm_new" and set the view to "//bccm/bccm_main/... //bccm/bccm_1_10/..." and click "Ok".  You can always look at other BCCM branch mappings under "Browse" on the "Merge/Integrate" dialog for examples.

 

After the two sub-tasks above have been completed, "Merge/Integrate" all of bccm_main's contents into the newly created bccm_new directory in Perforce.  This can be most easily done directly in Perforce using the "Selected changelists" filter method under the "Filter" tab in the "Merge/Integrate" dialog.  Make sure you keep track of the latest changelist number included and put this in the changelist description for the merge commit (that way the information is easy to reference when you go to write an email to alert the rest of dev/QA later).

 

 

Configuration of build files and assigning initial COE lock:

Files that need to be updated:

    • //bccm/bccm_new/kickstarts/branch_info
    • //bccm/bccm_new/kickstarts/mock
    • //bccm/bccm_new/p4.cs
    • //bccm/bccm_new/Makefile.defs
    • //bccm/bccm_new/pom.xml

 

Please reference changelists [812180, 812186, 812187, 812191] submitted against B#247262 for an example of what needs to be done for these files.

You will want to make sure that the COE lock you configure with these files matches the Koji tags for bccm_new (see Creating Koji Tags and Locking MC to COE release)

 

 

Remove any vestigial code that isn't actually part of the build.

The first part of ConfD/COE3 development took place on bccm_main a long time ago and was moved into it's own branch.  The //bccm/bccm_main/bluecoat-cm-confd/... directory was left over from this and will be deleted when we release MC on COE3.  Until then, it should be removed from release branches.  For reference, CL#812188 against B#247262 removed this code during bccm_1_10 release branch creation.  This is the only known chunk of completely dead code that needs to be removed when creating release branch.

 

 

Change internal components version (i.e. bundles, RPMs, other assorted files)

Follow the "General workflow" instructions in //bccm/dev_environment/tools/branching_helpers.

For example, CL#812263 against B#247262 changed the internal components version for the bccm_1_10 files.

 

 

Update development shell scripts (to use proper Java and JS compiler versions)

We have to make sure that the proper environment variables are being set for developers using our developer scripts (//bccm/dev_environment/tools/bccm_fns.sh).  For example, when bccm_1_10 was created we know it used the Java 8 compiler and the JavaScript compiler did not change so CL#812265 was committed against B#247262 to adjust the dev functions accordingly.

 

Also you should update the development environment install script to install the correct version of SenchaCmd  by modifying //bccm/dev_environment/scripts/sencha.sh (as was done in CL#828888 by Matt Sorensen).

 

 

Mass-merge syncing new changelists from bccm_main to bccm_new (optional)

If only a few changelists have been submitted since the Initial merge/population of the source tree bccm_main --> bccm_new step, we can just leave it up to the individual devs to manually merge those CLs into bccm_new.  If there has been a significant number of CLs submitted, we may want to do a mass-merge.  This can be most easily done directly in Perforce using the "Selected changelists" filter method under the "Filter" tab in the "Merge/Integrate" dialog.  Make sure you keep track of which changelists are included and put this in the changelist description for the merge commit (that way the information is easy to reference when you go to write an email to alert the rest of dev/QA later).

For example, during bccm_1_10 branch creation a mass-merge was done in CL#813619 against B#247262.

 

 

Creating Koji tags.

Use the "Create-Koji-Tag-Hierarchy" job on Jenkins (https://jenkins.bluecoat.com/view/Dev-Utils/job/Create-Koji-Tag-Hierarchy/) to create tags for bccm_new.  Usually when creating a release branch we will know which branch of COE we should be locking bccm_new to, but if you don't know you can always lock to the latest COE release and re-lock the branch again later (see Locking MC to COE release).

 

 

Checking build and dev environment locally for bccm_new

  • Manually review any files that required manually merging contents when resolving.
  • Check builds
    • Shell: (follow the instructions in the links replacing "bccm_main" with "bccm_new" where appropriate)
      • How do I build the MC 1.x shell binary?
      • How do I build the MC 1.x shell RPM for RHEL/CentOS/COE? (optional)

 

    • Appstats: (follow the instructions in the links replacing "bccm_main" with "bccm_new" where appropriate)
      • How do I build the Appstats binary for RHEL/CentOS/CLP?
      • How do I build the Appstats RPM for RHEL/CentOS/CLP? (optional)

 

    • MC Virgo client development overlay: (see also: How do I write Javascript in development mode?)
      • bccm_<branch>/bccm.client.dev# mvn clean install

 

    • MC top-level build:
      • bccm_<branch># mvn clean install -Pdevelopment,developmentMode

 

    • MC local dev runtime:
      • bccm_<branch>/bccm.rt.dev# mvn clean install

 

  • Check if MC runtime starts up on SDE Dev VM:
    • If you have the MC runtime running on any other branch, you should stop it before you start it for bccm_new.
    • bccm_<branch>/bccm.rt.dev/target/bin# ./startup.sh -debug
    • Use web browser to hit "http://ip.address.of.dev.machine:8080/"

 

 

Enable build jobs.

This can only be done by ES.  Hopefully they kept the original ticket you filed for branching tasks open and you can just update the that ES ticket to ask them to enable the jobs.  If they closed that ticket already, file a new ticket to DL-ENG-ES@symantec.com (optionally cc'ing Rajeev) and ask for bccm_new build jobs to be enabled.

 

 

Notification of dev team and QA that branch has been created.

A single authoritative email that covers all your bases is useful so that devs on the team know what's up without having to hunt around threads for info.

 

These emails should have a subject line of "bccm_<branch> branching" (e.g. "bccm_new branching") and give information about:

    • instructions for devs to get new branch running in SDE dev VM
    • instructions concerning manual propagation of commits by devs between main and new branch
    • changeslist numbers included in branch_new from bccm_main
    • changelist numbers that need to be propagated by devs
    • branch mappings in Perforce
    • state of branch with regards to cachezilla, koji, and perforce
    • external facing version number
    • internal components version number
    • COE lock state
    • dev build state
    • production build state
    • associated Cachezilla bug number(s) and ES ticket number(s) used in branch creation

 

     It is highly suggested to use the first email in the attached email thread as a template in crafting this notification.

content.text:
VA Creation

If you are deploying SSLV 3.x as a VA, see the document SSLV 3.x UI Virtual Machine "How To" for details concerning how to set up the VA in vSphere.[1]

 

Initial Configuration/Bootstrapping

Once a bootable SSLV system has been established/deployed, networking configuration must be applied to the machine.  There are really four general ways to accomplish network configuration/bootstrapping[2] and which one can/should be used highly depends on the platform and version being deployed:

 

DHCP (HW or VA)

This is the default for both HW and VA according to "Section 4: Initial Configuration and Setup" in Blue Coat® SSL Visibility Appliance Administration & Deployment Guide for v3.11.x.  However, it may be default only for SSLV 3.x installs, as the documentation for SSLV 4.0.1.x seems to indicate a standard ICW process (provided by COE 3.x )

 

Front panel (HW only)

This only applies to SSLV HW boxes.  You can do initial network bootstrapping with the font panel buttons on HW as detailed in the administration and deployment guides for SSLV that can be found on the Symantec product documentation page for SSLV.  For a SV1800, the relevant document is Blue Coat® Systems SV1800-C/-F Administration & Deployment Guide and the section "4. Initial Configuration and Setup" details the network configuration process.

 

Virtual Console (VA only)

The virtual console for the VA in vSphere will present you with a login screen[3], where you do the following:

    • Log in with username is 'bootstrap' and password 'bootstrap'.
    • Enter command: 'master key create'
    • Enter command: 'user add admin audit manage-pki manage-appliance manage-policy'
    • Enter the password you want for the 'admin' user on the CLI and UI
    • Log out by typing 'exit'
    • Log back in as 'admin' user this time.
    • Enter command: 'network set ip x.x.x.x netmask y.y.y.y gateway z.z.z.z'
    • Enter command: 'platform reboot'
    • You may seen an error on the virtual console[4] when the VA boots back up, it seems to be harmless.
    • Once the VA has finished rebooting, log into the UI at https://x.x.x.x/ and configure the "Management Network" "Primary Nameserver" and "Secondary Nameserver".

 

Serial connection (HW or VA)

Using physical serial port for HW or using virtual serial ports of a VA in vSphere.  (Note that this is not the same as the "virtual console" which is essentially the "monitor and keyboard" attached to the machine, for "serial console" we would be configuring vSphere to route traffic to/from the virtual serial port interface of the virtual machine.  This is a little complicated, but Waterloo teams have done this in the past for various VAs.)

 

Licensing

Once initial configuration is complete, you can log into the UI at https://<ip-address>/ and license the SSLV.  I licensed a VA with a license file procured by Dana Perry (a QA engineer on the SSLV team).  However, you should be able to download a license file from the Symantec Network Protection Licensing Portal provided you have a production serial number.

 

As always, this document will be updated as needed.  If you run through an SSLV install, please add any clarifying notes you deem necessary to this document so we can keep it as an accurate reference.

 

 

 

[1] For demonstration purposes this document assumes you chose to emulate a SV1800 and that the version of the SSLV is "SSLV Appliance 3.11.3.1-12V"

[2] "bootstrap" is a term that the SSLV team/documentation seems to use more than "initial configuration" which is the Blue Coat/COE standard terminology.

[3] Login screen for SSLV 3.11.x as seen in virtual console of vSphere on first boot prior to initial configuration:

[4] Error/Warning about keys after rebooting to make initial configuration take effect.  This seems to be a false alarm and did not prevent me from licensing the device:

content.text:
The Offline PDF Report Generator is capable of generating a fully formatted and stylized PDF from nothing but a POST-Request sent to the service with a JSON payload. This document is intended to focus specifically on Summary Reports (previously called executive reports) and how to build them from JSON.

 

All customization of the report is stored in the JSON.

 

Currently the following things ARE customizable globally:

  • Number of section and the names of each section
  • Order and size of reportlets
  • Data shown on each reportlet
  • Margins on the Top and Bottom of each reportlet
  • All reportlets stack vertically. Any reportlet that appears to be multiple reportlets in columns is actually a single reportlet.
  • All reportlets have their own customizations that can be controlled by the data under the "params" key of each reportlet.
  • Reportlet "params" are different for each type of reportlet, however, some global params exist, these include:
    • height
    • top-margin
    • bottom-margin
    • tableOfContents


Currently the following things are not customizable:

  • Page Size
  • Header/Footer Style and Layout
  • Header/Footer Logo
  • Page Orientation (Landscape/Portrait)
    • Portrait is the default
  • Custom CSS for reportlets
  • Global Margins (Edge Margins around each page)


JSON Documentation:

Important Fields


Three Root Options:

  • config: {}
    • Config does what one would expect. This provides global configuration for the document. Things like when the data was collected, the timezone, any custom header text and the report's title.
  • "sections":[]
    • Sections is a list of sections in the report. A section has it's own title page and will automatically paginate based on the number of reportlets used in the section.
  • "dataSets":[]
    • dataSets contain the actual information for the reportlets in the different sections.
    • Each dataset has a "dataSetId": "STRING" that is used to select the data to use in each reportlet.
    • A dataSet has all data in the same format that Reporter provides it. This is true even if the data didn't come from Reporter. You will have to marshal the data into the correct format in order to have the dataset be usable.



Reportlet Types and Params:


ALL TYPES:

These are params shared by all reportlets. All height or margins are in mm units.

 

Params

  • margin-top
    • Variable Type: Double/Float
    • Custom margin at the top of the reportlet in mm
  • margin-bottom
    • Variable Type: Double/Float
    • Custom margin at the bottom of the reportlet in mm
  • height
    • Variable Type: Double/Float
    • All reportlets have a default height. This will override that height and set a custom one.
  • tableOfContents
    • Variable Type: String
    • When this is present, an entry will be added to the table of contents page of the report.
  • EXAMPLE
    • reportlets: [{
        "type": "ANY_TYPE_HERE",
          "dataSetIds": ["my_cool_dataSetId"],
          "params": {
             "margin-top": 6.5,
             "margin-bottom": 3,       "height": 90.5,
             "tableOfContents": "Text to show in table of contents"
           }
        }



<HIGHCHART>_CHART:

All charts have the same param options right now. This might change in the future. To select the style of chart you want you must select a valid type.


Available Chart Types:

  • LINE_CHART
  • COLUMN_CHART
  • PIE_CHART
  • BAR_CHART


Note: ANY chart available in highcharts.js should actually work. These are just the ones I have actually tested so far. All you do is this: <HIGHCHART-TYPE>_CHART In that format it will grab the Highcharts chart type and attempt to render it like that. The default selection is column.     


Params

  • chartFieldIds
    • Variable Type: Array of Strings
    • These are the fieldIds from the dataset that you actually want in your chart.
  • colorMap
    • Variable Type: Object (Hashmap/Key-Value pair)
    • If you have custom colors that you want for a specific field, you can set that here.
    • colorMap Example:
      params: {
          ....
          colorMap: {
              "cs_host": "#2b3037",
              "hits": "#231f20"
          }
          ....
      }



GRID:

The GRID is basically just a table. The Grid will use all the rows it can from the dataSet provided or until the maxRows limit is hit.


Params

  • gridFieldIds
    • Variable Type: Array of Strings
    • These are the fieldIds from the selected dataSet that you would like to be included as a column in the grid.
  • maxRows
    • Variable Type: Integer
    • This is a param to set the max rows in a grid.
  • countingCol
    • Variable Type: Boolean
    • If this flag the left-most column will be a row count.
  • emphasizedFieldIds
    • Variable Type: Array of Strings
    • Any fieldId in this array will be bolded and emphasized when the grid is rendered.



REPORTLET_TITLE:

The reportlet title is a way to create text to display above or underneath any reportlet. This is a reportlet on it's own and isn't "attached" in anyway to a reportlet but is provided for convenience in adding labels wherever it's needed. This reportlet does not need a dataSetId.


Params

  • title
    • Variable Type: String
    • This is the main text for the title.
  • subTitle
    • Variable Type: String
    • This is the text to be placed under the main title as a subtitle.



SPACER:

The spacer isn't actually needed anymore. It doesn't have any of it's own params. It accepts the standard "height", "top-margin", "bottom-margin" and even "tableOfContents". This reportlet doesn't need a dataSetId and is only for adding blank space where it's wanted.



TOP5_LIST:

The Top Five List is basically a table of tables. There are subReportlets that render with a title and their own dataSetId. Any dataSetId must be provided in the dataSetIds array in the reportlet definition.


Params

  • subReportlets
    • Variable Type: Array of Objects (HashMap/Key-Value pair)
    • subReportlet params
      • title
        • Variable Type: String
        • Text to be used in the title.
      • dataSetId
        • Variable Type: String
        • A single dataSetId to identify the dataSet for the table.
  • EXAMPLE:
    [....
    {
            "type": "TOP5_LIST",
            "dataSetIds": [
                     "sites_by_total_bytes",
                     "sites_by_download",
                     "webapps_by_total_bytes",
                     "categories_by_total_bytes"
             ],
            "params": {
            "tableOfContents": "My Table of Contents Text",
            "subReportlets": [{
                        "title": "Top 5 Websites by Total Traffic",
                        "dataSetId": "sites_by_total_bytes"
                  },{
                        "title": "Top 5 Websites by Downloads",
                        "dataSetId": "sites_by_download"
                  },{
                       "title": "Top 5 Categories by Total Traffic",
                      "dataSetId": "categories_by_total_bytes"
                  },{
                       "title": "Top 5 Web Apps by Total Traffic",
                       "dataSetId": "webapps_by_total_bytes"
                  }]
            }
      },
    .....]



VALUE_CHANGE_DETAIL:

Value Change Detail's show three lines that represent a change in value. You need to provide three dataSetIds. One for the current data, one for the previous period, and one for the total.


Params

  • value1
    • Variable Type: String (DataSet Path)
    • This string defines the dataSetId and the path to the desired data
    • Example: <dataSetId>.<One Level Deep>.<Two Levels Deep>
  • value2
    • Variable Type: String (DataSet Path)
    • This string defines the dataSetId and the path to the desired data
    • Example: <dataSetId>.<One Level Deep>.<Two Levels Deep>
  • total1
    • Variable Type: String (DataSet Path)
    • This string defines the dataSetId and the path to the desired data
    • Example: <dataSetId>.<One Level Deep>.<Two Levels Deep>
  • text
    • Variable Type: String
    • This is just the text that you want to use as a title for the reportlet
  • EXAMPLE:
    [....
    {
          "type": "VALUE_CHANGE_DETAIL",
          "dataSetIds": ["blocked_sites", "blocked_sites:prev", "protocols"],
          "params": {
               "tableOfContents": "Blocked Traffic",
                "value1": "blocked_sites.total.hits",
                "value2": "blocked_sites:prev.total.hits",
                "total1": "protocols.total.hits",
                "text": "Blocked Requests"
          }
    }
    ....]

Note: The ":prev" in the example above is just part of the dataSetId string and is not required


VALUE_CHANGE_LINE:

This reportlet is a single line of data. You provide the text with a path to that data in {path.to.data} format, similar to the way it's done in VALUE_CHANGE_DETAIL.


Params

  • text
    • Variable Type: String
    • This text is the message that will be used to explain the meaning of the data.
  • value1
    • Variable Type: String (DataSet Path)
    • This is the newer data used for the percent change calculation
  • value2
    • Variable Type: String (DataSet Path)
    • This is the older data used for the percent change calculation
  • EXAMPLE:
    {
          "type": "VALUE_CHANGE_LINE",
          "dataSetIds": ["blocked_sites","blocked_sites:prev","browsing_per_site"],     
          "params": {
                "text": "of {browsing_sites.total.cs_host}" sites blocked",
                    "value1": "blocked_sites.total.cs_host",
                "value2": "blocked_sites:prev.total.cs_host"
          }

       }
