content.text:
Deployed Blue Coat products require Internet access so they can communicate with backend services to acquire birth certificates, license updates, and subscription feeds.  When deployed within the SDE, the boxes cannot directly hit these backend services and so the traffic must be routed through a single approved proxy that is setup and managed by the Secure Development Environment sub-department of Engineering Services.  So for example, with Management Center there is a CLI command to configure an explicit HTTP proxy which causes HTTP traffic generated by the MC to be forwarded to the proxy.  This allows us MC to communicate with the licensing servers in real time.

 

[Author's note]

The document below is the result of figuring out how to do this, however needing a Forward proxy config for ProxySG in the SDE to talk to SDE proxy is in fact documented already at: Accessing Blue Coat services through the SDE proxy  At the time of creation of this document, I was not aware that the other doc existed.  I am leaving the document I wrote here intact, as it provides a step-by-step guide that is more detailed and I think it still provides some utility (at least for me personally).

 

There is a similar configurable option for many Blue Coat products, but for ProxySG it is different.  To configure the same behavior on the ProxySG you must configure this using other, more advanced subsystems that are designed to do proxy forwarding in a general sense and hook into the standard policy evaluation logic.  Using these powerful parts of the ProxySG to configure this simple case of a single explicit HTTP is what this document covers.

 

There are two "Proxy"s, that is, there are two "ProxySG" appliances in our scenario.  Though only one of them is being used as an actual proxy, the other can be thought of as a generic appliance that needs to talk to the Internet.  To eliminate confusion, we will clearly define which proxy we're talking about where:

  • "Proxy P" -- This is the SDE perimeter proxy that sits on the edge of the SDE network and is the only way for deployed products inside the SDE to communicate directly to the Blue Coat/Symantec backend services outside the SDE.
  • "Proxy I" -- This is the ProxySG we are deploying inside the SDE that we need to configure to talk to backend services so we can license it and get a birth certificate, etc.

 

Two steps to configure Proxy I:

1) Configure the Proxy P as a Forwarding Host on Proxy I.  There are two ways to do this:

  1. CLI
    • Log into Proxy I CLI as admin
    • Enter "enable" mode.
    • Enter "config" mode.
    • Enter "forwarding" mode.
    • "create host <host-alias> drp-sde.bluecoat.com http=8080 proxy"
  2. UI
    • Log into Proxy I UI as admin.
    • Select "Configuration" tab.
    • Select "Forwarding" --> "Forwarding Hosts" in leftnav section.
    • Create new forwarding host:
      • Name (host-alias): <your choice, so long as it's valid>
      • Host: drp-sde.bluecoat.com
      • Server or Proxy: Proxy

 

2) Configure forwarding policy on Proxy I.  There are two ways to do this:

  • Deploy policy with Management Center.
    • Log into Management Center UI.
    • Add Proxy I as a device under the "Devices" leftnav tab.
    • Create a new policy object in under the "Configuration" --> "Policy" leftnav tab.
    • Add a new policy.
      • Policy name: <your choice, so long as it's valid>
      • Policy type: CPL
      • Reference ID: <auto-populated ID is okay>
      • Tenant: "default"
      • "Replace substitution variables" can be checked or unchecked; it is irrelevant to the policy we will use.
      • Finish the wizard.
    • Use the following policy text as a template for the new policy's "default" section content:

;; Tab :[Forwarding Layer]

<Forward>

     forward("<use_forwarding_host_alias_configured_earlier>") forward.fail_open(no)     ;Rule 1

    • Install the newly created policy by selecting it clicking the "Install" button and following the wizard:
      • "Basic Info" wizard page can be left as it is auto-populated.
      • Check the "Force installation" checkbox on the "Operation" page and leave the other values as set
      • Use "Selected Targets" on the "Targets" page and select Proxy I.
      • Schedule as "Immediate" in "Schedule" page and click "Finish".

 

  • Configure policy on Proxy I UI directly.
    • Select "Configuration" tab.
    • Select "Policy" --> "Visual Policy Manager" in leftnav section.
    • Launch VPM.
    • Select an existing "Forwarding Layer" tab or create a new one by clicking "Policy" --> "Add Forwarding Layer..." on the menubar.
    • Add a rule.
    • Right click under the "Action" column for your newly created rule and click "Edit".
    • Add the forwarding host for the that was previously configured to point to Proxy P.
    • The setting for "If no forwarding host is available:" can be left as "Deny the request (fail closed)".
    • Click "Ok".
    • Exit VPM and install the policy.

 

See Also:

ProxySG backend servers via other proxy

content.text:
Generic information regarding locking any application to a COE release can be found on the COE share space in Quick Reference: Building aginst COE and Locking Applications to a COE Release.

 

This document is specific to locking Management Center to a COE PIT build and serves as a supplement to Locking MC to COE release.

 

Essentially, a COE PIT build is just a build that has been released from COE dev to COE QA for qualification and acts as a pre-release that has a reasonable degree of stability. It is the latest COE code that is externally visible to product teams under normal circumstances [1].  When talking to COE team, the "latest" code is the PIT stuff and in Quick Reference: Building aginst COE the "latest code" == "PIT build".

 

Step #4 in Locking MC to COE release might not apply when locking to a PIT build.  Since a PIT build is pre-release, the COE team may not have published a version revved clpserviceutil JAR to Nexus, which we pull in with the top-level MC Maven build.  If you're locking for PIT, you probably want the latest released version of the COE JARs pulled into our build.  You can check which versions are available from a browser in the SDE: http://nexus.bluecoat.com:8081/nexus/content/groups/public/com/bluecoat/clp/clps erviceutil/.

 

 

As an example of locking to a PIT build, see B#244446 with associated changelist 804047.

See also: Office Terms and Acronyms for a definition of the term "PIT"




[1] Technically speaking, the latest COE code is on the internal COE dev branch (i.e. clp_2_0-dev for COE 2.x and coe3-dev for COE 3.x), however this is bleeding edge code that has absolutely zero guarantee of stability.  Locking to COE dev branch code is never done, but in theory you could (Process to pick up the latest COE code; warning this document may induce headaches, so try to use other documents referenced above instead)
